posts.name: Rhett Adam
posts.cooked:
It’s been a while since the last major Peekorobo update! With that, A LOT has changed.

To start, I have written new EPA models for every year from 1992-2025. The EPA model for 1992-2014 is the same because the API response before 2015 just provided an alliance total score and nothing else.

However, I analyzed the scoring capabilities and nuances of each game from 2015-2025 to craft unique EPA models for each. Along with the proprietary scoring metrics is an entirely new system for weighting matches and the “confidence” in a team.

A team’s final EPA is multiplied by a confidence value. This value is calculated by a weighted combination of three core factors: consistency, rookie status, and carry score.

Consistency measures how stable a team’s performance is across matches. It’s computed as

1 - (standard deviation / mean)

of their scoring contributions. A more consistent team earns a higher multiplier.

Rookie score rewards veteran teams by assigning a higher value (1.0) to teams that competed in the previous season, and a lower value (0.6) to rookies.

Rookie score rewards veteran teams by assigning a higher value (1.0) to teams that competed in the previous season, and a lower value (0.6) to rookies.

Carry score evaluates whether the team contributed a meaningful portion of their alliance’s EPA . It’s calculated as:

Carry score evaluates whether the team contributed a meaningful portion of their alliance’s EPA . It’s calculated as:

min(1.0, team_epa / (average_teammate_epa + ε))

where ε prevents division by zero. If a team often plays above the level of their alliance partners, this score trends higher.

The final confidence value is the average of these three metrics, clipped between 0.0 and 1.0. A team’s actual EPA is then:

actual_epa = overall_epa * confidence

This model not only reflects how much a team scores, but also how reliably they do it, and how much of the load they carry. Combined with game-specific logic for 2015–2025 and global alliance-score-based estimates from 1992–2014, Peekorobo’s EPA system now delivers the most nuanced performance metric it’s ever had.

Matches aren’t all treated equally:

Earlier matches weigh more heavily (via exponential decay ).

Qualification matches are weighted higher than playoff matches due to their random nature

A custom learning rate (K) adapts based on how many matches a team has played: Faster learning early on, slower (and more stable) later. This makes the model responsive but avoids overreacting to outliers.

Faster learning early on, slower (and more stable) later.

This makes the model responsive but avoids overreacting to outliers.

A trend delta is calculated, which sums recent EPA changes to reveal momentum:

Positive trend? You’re improving.

Negative? Time to retool. This is especially useful for mid-season scouting and gauging if a team is peaking or falling off.

Behind the scenes, the entire infrastructure of Peekorobo has been upgraded with a completely restructured SQLite database , purpose-built for speed and minimal footprint.

Despite tracking data from over 30 years of FRC history , the database now takes up significantly less space, with faster access times and more efficient updates.

I ran a performance test before and after integrating the new database. Both of these tests were performed by loading the 2025 team page for 2910 Jack in the Bot.

Old Test: Screenshot from 2025-04-06 00-57-25 1276×601 116 KB

Screenshot from 2025-04-06 00-57-25 1276×601 116 KB

Screenshot from 2025-04-06 00-57-25 1276×601 116 KB

The old test took 4.80 seconds to run. Yikes!

New Test: Screenshot from 2025-04-06 00-51-02 1276×601 111 KB

Screenshot from 2025-04-06 00-51-02 1276×601 111 KB

Screenshot from 2025-04-06 00-51-02 1276×601 111 KB

The new test only took 911 milliseconds to run! That’s not bad! Just by implementing a new database, loading times have been reduced by 5 times.

There have been some small UX updates for a more streamlined approach to analyzing matches from an individual team. Now, on each team page is a “Recent Events” section with a team’s rank, record, and matches with predictions.

image 1176×772 123 KB

image 1176×772 123 KB

image 1176×772 123 KB

Along with this, when you go to an event page, you can filter the matches by team:

image 831×848 111 KB

image 831×848 111 KB

image 831×848 111 KB

More to come soon—stay tuned!

Feel free to reach out if you have any suggestions, feedback, or concerns!

You can visit Peekorobo Here You can visit the GitHub Here

link_counts.title: GitHub - rhettadam/peekorobo: A web application that provides detailed insights into FIRST Robotics Competition teams.

posts.name: Abhijit Gupta
posts.cooked:
This is really cool! The website has a lot of features, including some I wished I had implemented in Statbotics but never got around to.

I noticed the match predictions are often in the 40-60% range. Have you tried measuring how often an alliance with a 60% predicted win rate actually wins? My hunch is your model might be under confident. If you’re measuring prediction accuracy per year, you could consider adding Mean Squared Error as a second metric to measure calibration. It would also help compare your model to OPR and EPA . Lastly, I worry if having two separate websites with separate EPA numbers will be confusing and hard to discuss. Have you considered another name for your metric?

posts.name: John Christiansen
posts.cooked:
Strategos:

Lastly, I worry if having two separate websites with separate EPA numbers will be confusing and hard to discuss. Have you considered another name for your metric?

The NFL’s EPA metric (and other advanced stats) has the same situation.  There are many sites that calculate their EPA metric slightly differently.  They handle it by trying to include the site or stat provider ie :“Statbotic’s EPA has them 5th” or “37.5 EPA per Peakorobo”.

Peakorobo looks great!  My team’s EPA is higher on Statbotics so I will continue using that, however.

posts.name: Griffin Della Grotte
posts.cooked:
Strategos:

Lastly, I worry if having two separate websites with separate EPA numbers will be confusing and hard to discuss. Have you considered another name for your metric?

XaulZan11:

They handle it by trying to include the site or stat provider ie :“Statbotic’s EPA has them 5th” or “37.5 EPA per Peakorobo”.

Second the request from @Strategos … I understand EPA is an existing term from Football, so it’s not like he invented it, but can we all just let statbotics.io own the term EPA for FRC ? Realistically people aren’t going to take the time to specify what source for EPA they’re using, so it’s just going to get confusing.

It’s not like there is a shortage of TLAs to pick from.

posts.name: Rhett Adam
posts.cooked:
Thanks so much! That really means a lot—Statbotics was a huge inspiration for Peekorobo, so I appreciate the kind words.

You’re absolutely right about the prediction confidence. I’ve noticed that same 40–60% clustering, especially in qualification matches where alliance strength is more random. Right now, the model leans conservative on purpose to avoid overfitting early in the season or on sparse data. That said, your point about calibration is spot on. I haven’t done a formal binning analysis yet (like checking how often 60% predictions win), but I definitely want to. Adding Mean Squared Error or Brier score per year is a great idea—I’ll look into it.

As for the EPA naming, yeah, I totally get the concern. I’ve been thinking about renaming it. I’d love any suggestions there. The goal is to be transparent and compatible, not confusing or competitive. Statbotics has built a fantastic shared language around EPA , and I want to make sure Peekorobo adds to it, not fragments it.

Let me know if you’d ever want to chat about it more in-depth—would be fun to cross-compare approaches!

posts.name: Rhett Adam
posts.cooked:
@Strategos Peekorobo’s performance model is officially called ACE (adjusted contribution estimate), which is essentially EPA x confidence. The website has been updated accordingly with all existing mentions of EPA replaced by ACE. I have made a blog page to better explain this:

A scouting and statistics platform for FRC teams that provides detailed insights and resources

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked:
Aren’t you supposed to be in college?

But actually this is an amazing website and I use it all the time and I know a lot of 1912 does as well. Keep up the good work.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Purely out of curiosity,

Is there a reason why you are not calling std. dev. / mean the coeff. of variation? Or rather why you went with 1 - (std. dev. / mean)

I absolutely agree with you this is the correct descriptive stat for looking at consistency, just not sure why you are not using the term (or one of the other terms for the same thing) / went with the 1 - CV approach.

Just trying to get a grasp on it

posts.name: Rhett Adam
posts.cooked: I’m using 1 - (std dev / mean) instead of just the coefficient of variation because it flips the scale to make the interpretation more intuitive—higher values mean more consistency. CV increases with variability, but for this use case, I wanted a consistency score where 1 means very consistent and 0 means very erratic. So it’s based on CV, just adjusted for easier interpretation.

posts.name: Rhett Adam
posts.cooked: God forbid a man has hobbies. But fr, thank you. I really appreciate it. I’ve put a lot of hard work into this website, and it means so much that it’s getting some use.
